description: Named after Christopher Pinchbeck, an 18th century London watchmaker who developed the alloy.

adjectives.description: pinchbeck (comparative more pinchbeck, superlative most pinchbeck)

entries.meaning: Sham; spurious, artificial; being a cheap substitution; only superficially attractive.
examples: Where, in these pinchbeck days, can we hope to find the old agricultural virtue in all its purity?

entries.meaning: An alloy of copper and zinc once used as imitation gold for cheap jewelry.
